Award.AwardTitle: Dissertation Research: Linking Phylogeny and Functional Morphology to Assess the Evolution of Gill Ventilation Systems in Teleost Fishes
Award.AbstractNarration:
To explore the evolution of complex functional anatomical systems, the researchers will study the respiratory apparatus in a diverse group of bottom-dwelling fishes (sculpins and allies). They will develop a new phylogenetic tree of relationships among 27 representative cottoid species based on DNA sequence data from four nuclear genes. The researchers will use dissection and computed tomographic (CT) scans to study anatomy of the respiratory apparatus and reconstruct its patterns of evolution. Functional consequences of these evolutionary anatomical changes will be studied using (1) an easily modified robotic model to simulate different types of fish breathing; and (2) pressure recordings from five representative species to assess the predictive power of the robotic model.

This research will contribute to the graduate education of doctoral candidate Stacy Farina. The robot will be used in a workshop for the Expanding Your Horizons conference at Cornell University, which provides STEM experiences for 7-9th grade girls. While the focus of this study is on sculpins and allies, variation in cottoid anatomy is such that findings will be broadly applicable to many other groups of fishes. This project will also contribute to the development of techniques for using robotic models to study evolution of complex biomechanical systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Animals must perform a variety of functions to survive, such as eating, breathing, and avoiding predators. These functions require coordination of many anatomical systems and therefore can be quite complex. How do such complicated systems evolve? To answer this question, biologists must first understand how anatomy changes over time and how those changes impact function. One of the most important functions in fishes is the process of moving water over (ventilating) the gills. For this project, the PIs examined links among changes in anatomy and the resulting changes in function in aquatic gill ventilation. 

Specifically, the PIs studied anatomy and function of gill ventilation within a group of bottom-dwelling fishes that includes sculpins, poachers, snailfishes, lumpsuckers, and relatives (the Cottoidei). The PIs used micro-computed tomography (micro-CT) to scan 20 cottoid species and reconstruct their skeletal morphology to measure each bone in three-dimensional space. The PIs assembled an evolutionary tree of relationships among 106 cottoid species using available genetic data. They used this tree to map the evolution of bones within the skull and relate these patterns to the evolution of both gill ventilation and feeding systems within the group. The PIs also developed two versions of a robotic model of gill ventilation. They varied motor patterns to produce large differences in water movements that correspond to flow variation seen in fishes with differently sized gill chamber structures. Both projects demonstrate and quantify the importance of gill chamber structures in producing the vast diversity seen in gill ventilatory function.

In the time-frame of this award, the graduate student Co-PI also published the results of a large survey of gill opening morphology across fishes and a project on gill ventilation in goosefish. She also completed and defended her doctoral dissertation. She mentored three undergraduate research projects on topics within anatomy and function of marine vertebrates. She also received training in working with 3D datasets and in evolutionary analyses. She presented her research at five national and two international meetings.

The PIs deposited more than 100 fish specimens into the Cornell University Museum of Vertebrates and made micro-CT datasets available to other researchers and to the public. The graduate student Co-PI helped to organize a Summer 2015 working group at a marine field station on analyzing CT datasets. She also organized an annual marine biology workshop each year for the Expanding Your Horizons program, which offers workshops for 7­-9th grade girls to encourage interest in STEM careers. She also operated a science-themed Twitter account, where she has tweeted images of CT scans and her robotic model and has discussed her research projects. She helped to engage the public in the topic of fish biomechanics by co-authoring a news article in a widely-read journal and by providing an interview on her CT scanning research for a magazine.
